title: NASA’s PACE Climate Sat Ready to Fly
summary: After nearly nine years of planning, preparation, and even once being slated for cancellation entirely, NASA’s Plankton, Aerosol, Cloud, ocean Ecosystem (PACE) Earth-observation mission is set for launch. Initially conceived in 2015, PACE will finally reach orbit and begin its planned  3-10 year mission on a launch currently slated for February 6, 2024 at 1:33 AM.

title: The last vestige of old space architectural thinking
summary: Despite the recent explosive increase in launch cadence, ground systems tend to be outdated, underfunded, and overlooked.

title: HyImpulse Are All Packed and Heading Down Under
summary:
German launch startup HyImpulse has confirmed that its SR75 rocket and all related support systems have been boxed up and have embarked on the long journey to Australia. SR75 is a single-stage suborbital launch vehicle that is designed to be capable of delivering up to 250 kilograms to a maximum altitude of around 200 kilometres. […]
The post HyImpulse Are All Packed and Heading Down Under appeared first on European Spaceflight.

title: NASA compiling lessons learned from Artemis 1
summary: NASA is wrapping up an effort to collect lessons learned from the Artemis 1 mission that address both technical and programmatic issues that the agency hopes to apply more broadly to the overall Artemis lunar exploration campaign.

title: Exolaunch Awarded First European Space Agency Launch Contract
summary:
German payload aggregator and in-space logistics company Exolaunch has been awarded a contract to launch the European Space Agency’s (ESA) Arctic Weather Satellite (AWS). In addition to being the first ESA launch contract awarded to the Berlin-based company, the awarding also marks a significant milestone for the agency as the first launch contract awarded through […]
The post Exolaunch Awarded First European Space Agency Launch Contract appeared first on European Spaceflight.

title: NASA Earth science mission once slated for cancellation ready for launch
summary: A nearly billion-dollar mission to study the Earth’s oceans and atmosphere is ready to launch after surviving several cancellation attempts earlier in its development.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy February 4-10, 2024
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of February 4-10, 2024 and any insight we can offer about them.  The Senate and House are in session […]

title: China launches 20 satellites on separate inland and sea rocket launches
summary: A pair of Chinese rockets launched 11 mobility services satellites for an automaker and nine further, diverse satellites into orbit late Friday.

title: Inland spaceports seek ways to host orbital launches
summary: With congestion growing at the nation’s major launch sites in California and Florida, operators of inland spaceports are seeking creative ways to host orbital launches.

title: While Artemis II schedule remains uncertain, NASA EGS preparing to be ready and waiting for stacking
summary: At the Kennedy Space Center (KSC), NASA’s Exploration Ground Systems (EGS) program continues to prepare for the Artemis II circumlunar mission that was recently delayed to September 2025. EGS is finishing certification of new ground systems to support crewed launches of the agency’s Orion spacecraft with its Space Launch System (SLS) rocket beginning with Artemis II.
